    Head 0701 -

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0701 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*.(* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs Yeo Choo Kok, Ho See Beng and Seah Mui Kok.)

    Sir, in the last Budget session, I spoke on staff shortage in the Telecommunications Department of the Ministry of Communications. Let me quote what I said on the 19th March last year [Hansard, Vol. 30, No. 13, col. 889]:

    `... we have a very serious shortage of staff in the Telecommunications Department. The employees in the operational side of the department work day in and day out without obtaining any time off for rest days and public holidays.'

    Sir, last year, the International Telegraph Section of the Telecommunications Department alone owed the staff for the period June 1969 to January 1971 a total of 30,000 hours for working on rest days and public holidays. The Department owed the messengers 11,500 hours, clerical assistants 5,600 hours, and counter clerks 1,500 hours. I also mentioned then, Sir, the fact that messengers were put on duty without a single day of rest for several weeks at a stretch. They worked for half a year without any rest days or public holidays. I also mentioned the fact that there should not be any problem at all in recruiting clerical assistants, counter clerks and messengers because they are not highly skilled persons.

    Let me now quote to you, Sir, what the Minister told this House then, and I quote from the same Hansard, col. 892:

    `I am very pleased to say that for the first time the department is well ahead on recruitment. The Public Service Commission has just completed an exercise to recruit over

Column: 772



250    Telecommunications clerical assistants and technicians. This will wipe out the present vacancy position as well as fill the 159 new posts now coming up for approval before the House. The department should be able to have a full complement of staff by May this year.'

That was the reply last year. And he continued:

    `A crash training programme is being arranged which will enable the new staff to be trained and put into operating position some time in August. It is anticipated that the long overdue time off can be granted thereafter.

    It is likely that 24 vacancies in the vote for telegraph messengers will be filled by June, by which period time off for messengers can be granted thereafter.'

    Sir, I will relate also what actually is the position today. It is strange, but true, that although the Minister for Communications assured me on 19th March last year that the loyal and dedicated staff of the Telecommunications Department would not again be faced with an enormous accumulation of time off, for this year, i.e., from March 1971 to February 1972, the figure stands at 45,000 hours owing to the staff in the department. Sir, the workers in the department cannot be treated as cogs in the wheels of the department. They should be given justice. It would seem odd indeed that such a situation exists in the Telecommunications Department since, as the Minister intimated last year, the Public Service Commission had just completed an exercise to recruit over 250 Telecoms clerical assistants and technicians and that the 24 vacancies for telegraph messengers would be filled by June. Sir, what has actually gone wrong? Was the recruitment done? Were the people recruited at all? My firm suspicion is it has broken down. Let us hope not. The department is expanding with greater demands for higher technological Telecommunications. Rapid advancement has been achieved with the installation of the satellite earth station and the expansion of the telex service. But to keep pace with this rapid development in the department, staffing should also be increased commensurate with the development. Sir, progress, cannot be

Column: 773

achieved without adequate, contented, and well-rested staff. May I suggest that the Minister radically revises the present situation existing in the Telecommunications Department to ensure that the defects are remedied without prejudice to any better provision which may exist or may be negotiated by the N.T.U.C.

    Sir, now that the Telecommunications Department is to be made the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore from 1st April this year, will this improve the situation at all? I have my doubts. Another statutory board, the Public Utilities Board, has similar problems of overtime and staffing. Do I have to come back again next year and make the same plea on behalf of the workers of the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore?

    An hon. Member: Will you be here next year?

    Mr N. Govindasamy: I will be here next year!

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, it does appear to be a repeat performance on the part of the Member for Telok Blangah in respect of the Telecommunications Department. He has asked whether anything has gone wrong with the Telecommunications Department. The answer is: nothing has gone wrong. It is only that the growth of traffic has been more than normal. Because of the very rapid expansion and demands from the commercial public, the Telecommunications Department could only meet this abnormal demand by involving the staff in overtime.

    He has quoted passages from Hansard in respect of the previous year's Budget. Vacancies then were being filled. The Public Service Commission did interview the candidates concerned, and it is normal for applicants to be interviewed around February-March when the results of the Secondary IV examinations are known. I think that is normal procedure. So once again in February-March

Column: 774

this year there would be another recruitment of staff to fill any vacancies. But may I, in reply, provide some figures too, for the benefit of the hon. Member? At the beginning of the last financial year, there were 166 vacancies for operational staff and 57 vacancies for technicians, which represent a vacancy percentage of about 20 per cent and 16 per cent respectively. It is very high, and I think it is unfair to the workers on the establishment having to work overtime to fill this gap. 174 operational staff and 51 technicians were recruited during the year. That would have virtually filled all the vacancies, but unfortunately with recruitment there were also resignations or retirements. There was a staff reduction of this nature by as many as 67 operational staff and 25 technicians (the word "wastage" was being used), leaving us with 59 vacancies - 4 operational staff and 31 technicians - waiting to be filled. This represents a reduced rate of vacancy percentage at only seven per cent and nine per cent respectively. I think if we compare with the previous `year's rate of vacancy percentage of 20 per cent and 16 per cent, we can say that there has been an improvement in the situation. However, selection of candidates to fill these remaining vacancies has just been completed, and it is envisaged that most, if not all, of the vacancies for operational staff and technicians, will be filled shortly.

    The Member has partly answered his own query when he touched on the establishment of the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore in 10 days time. The Telecommunications Department which is now part of a Government Ministry will be converted into a statutory organisation, and one of the reasons why we are converting it is to give it more flexibility in the recruitment and employment of staff. It may not be necessary, for example, to recruit staff annually. The new Authority will be in a position to recruit staff as and when it, is necessary and to decide on the salary scales, bearing in mind the Government salary structure and terms and conditions

Column: 775

of service. As a statutory organisation, it will certainly be able to move much more quickly in dealing with overtime problems like we have now.

    With regard to overtime, may I say that the position is not as bad as that stated by the Member, who quoted the figure of thousands of hours of overtime due. Time-off, which was earned and accumulated up to 31st December, 1970, has been converted to leave, and such leave was commuted to overtime pay at normal rates of salary. So money has been paid for overtime which has been accumulated prior to that date. But from 1971 onwards, the accumulation began to build up once again and this will have to be adjusted at some future date. However, I can assure the Member for Telok Blangah that it will not be necessary for him to repeat a third performance at the next Budget.

2.45 p.m.

    Head 0703 -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker. Sir, I beg to move.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0703 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*.(* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr P. Govindaswamy.)

    Sir, under this subhead, I would like to touch on two matters relating to the Paya Lebar Airport. I hope the Minister

Column: 776

will pay special attention to them because of certain complaints I have received.

    The first complaint is that the officers of the Immigration Department at the Paya Lebar Airport are not very efficient. The number of porters at the Airport is also too small. There is a need for more porters. Being an international airport, the traffic has been increasing every year. At present the number of passengers is nearly two million a year. This shows that more and more travellers are coming from abroad. Therefore, we must extend the highest standard of service to them in order to impress them, so that they will spread our good reputation abroad.

    I understand that the Government has made provision for a few million dollars for the development of Paya Lebar Airport, which includes the extension of the runway and the building of a new hangar to accommodate the Boeing 747. This type of passenger air liner requires the redevelopment of the Passenger Terminal Building. In view of all this, we hope that our civil aviation services will reach international standards, which, I think, is the aim of the Government. We should maintain a reasonable standard of service. Therefore, all the staff at the Airport, including the staff of the Immigration Department, should provide an efficient service. They should be courteous to the tourists, so that those coming from abroad will have a better impression of Singapore.

    However, Sir, I regret to say that recently I have received some complaints from members of the public to the effect that the staff at the Paya Lebar Airport were rather slow in rendering their services. For instance, air travellers have to take two or three minutes, and sometimes even up to five minutes, to be cleared at the Immigration counter. If there are 100 passengers arriving, how long will that take to clear? It may be that they are too busy.

Column: 777



    I have also received complaints that some of the staff on duty used to crack jokes among themselves. They are thus wasting their time and prolonging the waiting time of the passengers. This is uncalled for, and I would like the Minister to look into this matter and take measures to remedy the situation.

    There are also complaints about the shortage of porters. According to my information, there are only three porters to cope with more than 100 passengers. Obviously this number is not enough. If at times the porters are weak, the luggage will be thrown about because they cannot carry them. They are not able to cope with so many passengers.

    I have to bring all these complaints to the attention of the Minister because the number of tourists is increasing and our Government is spending a lot of money on civil aviation, particularly in the development of the airport. We should see to it that our civil servants there render a high international standard of service.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is only a limited staff at the tax-free store for passengers at the Transit section of the Paya Lebar Airport to cope with the present increased passenger load. Can the Airport authorities look into this matter to increase the staff of the store?

    What measures have been introduced at the Airport to prevent the hijacking of aircraft, now that hijacking has become a popular sport for neurotics and political desperadoes? If there is any special device, is it used to check on all the passengers? Are there any measures for all passengers to go through a screening device?

    What plans have been made for the use of Changi Airfield now that the British troops have withdrawn? Can the facilities available at Changi be considered for use in conjunction with Paya Lebar Airport, so that it forms an extension of the Airport services, particularly for chartered flights?

Column: 778



    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would just like to comment on the Member for Sembawang's allegation with regard to the slowness of the Immigration counter officers at the Airport in clearing passengers. Perhaps, if he would care to go to the Arrival Lounge in the new Passenger Terminal- I believe it is upstairs - he would be able to see a few counters where several Immigration officials are at work. I once had an occasion to visit this Terminal Building, and saw quite a good number of passengers coming through the Lounge. Judging from the speed with which Immigration clearance was made, and this is based on personal experience, I think the Member is exaggerating when he says that it takes two to three minutes, or even five minutes, to clear each passenger. However, he is more or less correct in his remarks about the Customs and Excise counter, because over there the passengers upon arrival will have to declare themselves, and for this reason there may be a little delay. I hope my clarification will help the Minister for Communications.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am always grateful to Members sitting on the Opposite bench, answering on my behalf. It does help now and again to have your ball at the other man's foot.

    May I now refer to the point raised by the Member for Sembawang regarding complaints against the Immigration Department. Strictly speaking, this is something not within my portfolio. Immigration Department comes under the Ministry of Home Affairs, and my colleague, who is the Minister, is having a good laugh behind me. It is quite likely that the complaints received by the Member were in respect of persons whom the Immigration Department were quite interested in and, therefore, probably a little longer time was taken before they could be cleared at the Arrival Hall. However, the Airport does provide adequate facilities for the Immigration Department.

Column: 779



    In our view, ever since the completion of the short-term development of our Airport costing $10 million, the floor area in the Passenger Terminal Building has been doubled from over a hundred thousand square feet to 270,000 square feet. The clearance facilities for passengers in respect of Health, Customs and Immigration have, therefore, improved. For the information of the Member, there are six triangular counters corresponding to six channels at the Arrival Hall for Immigration authorities to process arriving passengers simultaneously. In addition, there are two other counters behind the main Immigration counter to be used for checking arriving passengers who have no documents or whose documents are improper. Probably these are the people who have been complaining to the Member. If they had the proper documents, it would have been very simple for them to gain entry into Singapore. In our view, these eight Immigration counters are adequate to cope with passenger arrivals even during the evening peak period.

    As regards the complaint about baggage handling, which is under my portfolio and for which I am responsible, the problem has probably arisen because there is more than one organisation handling the baggage. It is our intention to have one Baggage Authority in the near future. Anyway, may I say that even at this moment, there are four different organisations handling the baggage. Firstly, the Malaysia-Singapore Airlines handles baggage of more than half of all the airlines that come into Singapore. There are, in all, 24 international airlines. M.S.A, handles at least one-half the number of airlines' bag-gages. The others are Pan-American, Garuda and, lastly, the Civil Aviation Department.

3.00 p.m.

    The Civil Aviation Department handles seven airlines. Sir, if there is one authority, we do agree that it would be more efficient. We know exactly who is responsible. But when an aircraft comes in and four authorities have got to find out which one of

Column: 780

them is responsible, inevitably some delay is involved. Whatever it is, after the $10 million short-term development of the Airport, we now have at the Arrival Hall five conveyor belts for the conveyance of baggage from the ramp to the baggage claim area. In our view, these five conveyors are adequate to cope with the demand at peak periods. The time taken for the baggage to be transported to the Arrival Hall at the Airport depends on the handling capacity of the airline or agent, which is responsible for it, and also the number of aircraft that lands at any one given time. If there were four landings within the space of half an hour, then of course there would be a big jam. It also depends on the location of the parking bays where the aircraft are ultimately parked. Anyway, may I say that normally baggage should be available for claiming in the baggage claim area within five minutes after the arrival of the aircraft which, I think, is a very good time. And this is the normal handling time undertaken by the Department of Civil Aviation for the seven airlines which it is in charge of.

    Coming to the question raised by the Member for Anson, he understands that there is not enough staff for the tax-free store in the Transit lounge. This matter will be conveyed to the Department of Civil Aviation to see that the store does provide adequate staff. May I add, Sir, that the stores at our Airport are doing such good business and, believe it or not, the rental for a store is not less than $40,000 a month, or half a million dollars a year, because we have at least two million people -as many as the population of Singapore-using our Paya Lebar Airport. If the concessionaire is able to pay half a million dollars in rent for a store in the Airport, he will see to it that there are more than adequate staff to handle the business because more staff means more business, and ultimately more profits.

    The Member also raised the problem of hijacking of aircraft. As you know, Mr Speaker, Sir, we have passed a Bill sometime ago to enable the Government

Column: 781

to comply with the so-called Tokyo Convention, which takes strong measures against hijacking. I believe our staff in the Department of Civil Aviation is quite wide awake to this possibility and, together with the representatives of international airlines, they are taking all steps to ensure that maximum security is maintained. Sometimes it may bring about some delay to passengers leaving or arriving at our Airport. I hope that if Members get complaints in future, they will understand that it is not because we are a little sticky about security, but because we have to be a little longer on the ground rather than something to happen up in the air.

    Lastly, the question whether or not Changi Airport can be used as an extension of Paya Lebar Airport for charter flights. Sir, there is a possibility that Changi Airport may be reverted to civilian use. It is now being reserved by the Ministry of Defence. They want it as a military airport. But there is no reason why Changi Airport may not be partly used for civil aircraft if air traffic continues to increase. May I say that, at the present moment, Paya Lebar Airport is not fully stretched. The present traffic is equivalent to about 40 per cent of what it can take. As and when it does come close to 80 or 90 per cent, then perhaps we can divert some of the chartered air flights from Paya Lebar to Changi Airport. But should it be necessary for Paya Lebar Airport to be closed, we do have arrangements whereby aircraft are advised to land at Changi Airport instead. So there is really no problem to use Changi Airport as an extension of Paya Lebar Airport, as and when the necessity arises.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, is it the opinion of the Minister for Communications that what I have said does not exist? In any case, if the Minister has the time, or his Parliamentary Secretary if he has no time, he should investigate into this complaint. If there is no truth, then it

Column: 782

is all the better. But if there is some truth, then there must be some improvement to our services. It is my hope that our high standards will be maintained.

    However, in view of the explanation given, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Sir, if my understanding is correct, Simbang Aerodrome was taken over by the Government from the British Forces. My queries to the Minister are: (1) where is this aerodrome sited, and what does the Government propose to do for its future use? (2) if it is to be used for civil aviation, for which a sum is provided, what type of aircraft will be allowed to operate in this aerodrome? and (3) why are only fire-fighting services stationed in this aerodrome, instead of an administrative set-up? Will the Minister clarify, please?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, I would like to inform the Member for Mountbatten that Simbang Aerodrome is a military aerodrome situated in Sembawang, and was vacated by the British Armed Forces. That being so, it came under the control of the Ministry of Defence. However, at the request of the M.I.D., the Department of Civil Aviation is responsible for providing the fire-fighting services, both at Simbang Aerodrome and the missile base.

Column: 783



    As regards the type of aircraft that will make use of Simbang Aerodrome, I assume that it will be military aircraft, and not civil aircraft. If more interest is shown, perhaps the Member can inquire from the Ministry of Defence officials.

    Head 0704 -

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0704 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001.

    Sir, now that Singapore has built a satellite earth station in Sentosa, may I know if the Meteorological Services Department is keeping up with the latest in weather forecasting, if such facilities are available? If the Department says there will be no rain today, but it does rain, then they are incorrect. They should have more forecasting stations in order to give better information to the public.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the comment made by the Member for Anson is that there is rain today but our Meteorological Department says there is no rain. This is not something unusual in Singapore. It happens in the best of cities. If you take a newspaper and the weather forecast says "No rain", it means, bring your umbrella!

Column: 784



    He has, however, mentioned the fact that since the Telecommunications Department is reasonably up to-date with the satellite earth station, should not our Meteorological Department also keep pace with technological advances? Sir, I wish to assure him that our Meteorological Services Department is reasonably up to scratch with international requirements, because it falls on the Department to provide meteorological services for civil aviation as well as for shipping. And they have to conform to international standards stipulated by the World Meteorological Organisation as well as the International Civil Aviation Organisation, so that constant efforts are always being made by the Department to ensure strict observance of these international standards.

    To cope with the new development in meteorology and to provide improved quality of service, the Department has, over the past three years, acquired a number of sophisticated meteorological instrumentation. This includes a ground satellite station to receive meteorological data from orbiting satellites, as distinct from the telecommunication satellite. There is also a 10-centimetre radar at Paya Lebar capable of detecting storms within 400 kilometres from Singapore. There are also two other weather radars of lesser range at Changi and Tengah Aerodromes, and a new wind-finding radar and telecommunication equipment for the prompt reception of computer-produced weather charts from overseas meteorological stations. The Department also supplied a large volume of climatologically information to commercial and scientific organisations and Government departments for their varied purposes such as factory siting, off-shore drilling operations, engineering construction and also air pollution studies.

3.15 p.m.

    During the North-east monsoons, warnings of prolonged and heavy rainfall likely to cause flooding are broadcast over Radio and Television.

Column: 785

Furthermore, a daily weather outlook forecast has been issued to the press for publication since 1970. The compact size of Singapore, the absence of distinct seasons - we have perpetual summer, we do not have the four seasons in Singapore - and the character of local tropical weather, all these factors necessarily impose a limitation on the accuracy of this daily forecast. So it could be "Fair weather this afternoon", but it rained before 12 o'clock. What could we do?

    Head 0705 -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    The total vote for Postal Services this year amounts to more than $22 million, showing an increase of over $400,000 as compared to last year. This means that an increase of population and the development of commercial and trade services have caused an increase of mail in Singapore, thereby increasing the workload of the Postal Department. Undeniably, the Postal Services Department in Singapore has all along enjoyed a reputation of high standards, it provides very good service to the people of Singapore and is a source of our pride.

    However, following the increase in population and of requirements and a shift in population, the degree of efficiency has been affected. As a result of this, I have received several complaints recently against delays in the delivery of domestic mail. It normally takes about two to three days to deliver a

Column: 786

letter locally. This is quite true, because I have some personal experience. For example, a certain friend of mine rang me up one day and asked, "Have you received my invitation card?"
